metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: jQuery Effects - Animation
With jQuery, you can create custom animations.
content.html: With jQuery, you can create custom animations.

content.text: jQuery Animations - The animate() Method
The jQuery animate() method is used to create custom animations.
content.html: The jQuery animate() method is used to create custom animations.

content.text: Syntax:
The required params parameter defines the CSS properties to be animated.
content.html: The required params parameter defines the CSS properties to be animated.

content.text: The optional speed parameter specifies the duration of the effect. It can take the following values: "slow", "fast", or milliseconds.
content.html: The optional speed parameter specifies the duration of the effect. It can take the following values: "slow", "fast", or milliseconds.

content.text: The optional callback parameter is a function to be executed after the animation completes.
content.html: The optional callback parameter is a function to be executed after the animation completes.

content.text: The following example demonstrates a simple use of the animate() method; it moves a <div> element to the right, until it has reached a left property of 250px:
content.html: The following example demonstrates a simple use of the animate() method; it moves a <div> element to the right, until it has reached a left property of 250px:

content.code_html:
$("button").click(function(){
  $("div").animate({left: '250px'});
});

content.text: By default, all HTML elements have a static position, and cannot be moved. To manipulate the position, remember to first set the CSS position property of the element to relative, fixed, or absolute!
content.html:
By default, all HTML elements have a static position, and cannot be moved.
To manipulate the position, remember to first set the CSS position property of the element to relative, fixed, or absolute!

content.text: jQuery animate() - Manipulate Multiple Properties
Notice that multiple properties can be animated at the same time:
content.html: Notice that multiple properties can be animated at the same time:

content.code_html:
$("button").click(function(){
  $("div").animate({
    left: '250px',
    opacity: '0.5',
    height: '150px',
    width: '150px'
  });
});

content.text: Is it possible to manipulate ALL CSS properties with the animate() method? Yes, almost! However, there is one important thing to remember: all property names must be camel-cased when used with the animate() method: You will need to write paddingLeft instead of padding-left, marginRight instead of margin-right, and so on. Also, color animation is not included in the core jQuery library. If you want to animate color, you need to download the Color Animations plugin from jQuery.com.
content.html:
Is it possible to manipulate ALL CSS properties with the animate() method?

Yes, almost! However, there is one important thing to remember: all property names must be camel-cased when used with the animate() method: You will need to write paddingLeft instead of padding-left, marginRight instead of margin-right, and so on.

Also, color animation is not included in the core jQuery library.
If you want to animate color, you need to download the Color Animations plugin from jQuery.com.

content.text: jQuery animate() - Using Relative Values
It is also possible to define relative values (the value is then relative to the element's current value). This is done by putting += or -= in front of the value:
content.html: It is also possible to define relative values (the value is then relative to the element's current value). This is done by putting += or -= in front of the value:

content.code_html:
$("button").click(function(){
  $("div").animate({
    left: '250px',
    height: '+=150px',
    width: '+=150px'
  });
});

content.text: jQuery animate() - Using Pre-defined Values
You can even specify a property's animation value as " show ", " hide ", or " toggle ":
content.html: You can even specify a property's animation value as "show", "hide", or "toggle":

content.code_html:
$("button").click(function(){
  $("div").animate({
    height: 'toggle'
  });
});

content.text: jQuery animate() - Uses Queue Functionality
By default, jQuery comes with queue functionality for animations.
content.html: By default, jQuery comes with queue functionality for animations.

content.text: This means that if you write multiple animate() calls after each other, jQuery creates an "internal" queue with these method calls. Then it runs the animate calls ONE by ONE.
content.html: This means that if you write multiple animate() calls after each other, jQuery creates an "internal" queue with these method calls. Then it runs the animate calls ONE by ONE.

content.text: So, if you want to perform different animations after each other, we take advantage of the queue functionality:
content.html: So, if you want to perform different animations after each other, we take advantage of the queue functionality:

content.code_html:
$("button").click(function(){
  var div = $("div");
  div.animate({height: '300px', opacity: '0.4'}, "slow");
  div.animate({width: '300px', opacity: '0.8'}, "slow");
  div.animate({height: '100px', opacity: '0.4'}, "slow");
  div.animate({width: '100px', opacity: '0.8'}, "slow");
});

content.text: The example below first moves the <div> element to the right, and then increases the font size of the text:
content.html: The example below first moves the <div> element to the right, and then increases the font size of the text:

content.code_html:
$("button").click(function(){
  var div = $("div");
  div.animate({left: '100px'}, "slow");
  div.animate({fontSize: '3em'}, "slow");
});

content.text: jQuery Exercises
Test Yourself With Exercises
Exercise:
Use the animate() method to move a <div> element 250 pixels to the right.
content.html: Use the animate() method to move a <div> element 250 pixels to the right.

content.code_html: $("div").animate({: ''});

content.text: Start the Exercise
jQuery Effects Reference
For a complete overview of all jQuery effects, please go to our jQuery Effect Reference .
content.html: For a complete overview of all jQuery effects, please go to our jQuery Effect Reference.
